document.text: years ago, says he has seen A lot of economic growth in the county since Fve been in business. Wilbun says there are more reason for people, particularly jroung people, to stay in the county. The industries, such as Armstrong, and the garment factories, have provided mere jobs and increased peoples spending power. Our business has improved every year, and I fee! like its due to the fact th at Appom attox is a growing community, Wilbun says. While the county has grown steadily in recent years, it has not progressed without growiqk pains- Ben Marshall w in opened his Main S treet Department S to tt in 1908, notes that our growth U td temmunity has boon dramatic, eapUCbffly in recent year. The shopping otor, for example, hah helped the county as a whole by increasing volume.  However. Marshall adds, things arent all rosy. We need to critique the past 30 years, and prehaps plan now for the future. Marshall feels that the downtown shopping area in particular, needs to be examined. There is a need for help dqwntown .Marshall notes, but. with the help sould come from a stimulus within the merchants. That is what would create economic growth. Lloyd Vaughan, the president of the Appomattox County Chamber of Commerce, notes that he fqois the auntys growth and progress have been steady since I cams here 21 years ago after purchasing the Thwes Vlr- gteian newspaper. Vaughan, who now , own and operates Appomatox Office Supply points out that ho quality Of life here

document.text: wrote Santa when I first learned to scribble, and I still believe. Of course, I believe in Santa Claus. Right now, he is No. One.-   . Our basketball teams are doing well. Thé compétition is strong in the Sem inole League and ÀCH8 has a chance for the title.    The 21st birthday is a big one for a young man and Monday. Dec. 14 was the big day for my friend. Bill Vaughan, son of Mr. and Mrs. W, Lloyd Vaughan, BiH is a student at Ferrum.      Have Been watching the-ads to find out hat toys and gifts m e most popular this year. Dolls still popular, a ère. games and mechanical toys. Wish my electric trains were operational but I just have not gotten around to get them

document.text: Writers Final Word Taking up the pen to write this article for the Times-Vir ginian, I find a note of sadness j in my heart. The many readers have been so gracious in their  response, and I know I have many unseen friends. Through this medium for the past two or more years you have made it possible for me to ex press some of my views, and at titudes about life and religion. The many expressions, from you have enriched my life. You have been gracious to write me from time to time. To Mr. Lloyd Vaughan, th e ! Owner-Publisher, let me say Thank you. Your willingness to allow me to express my thoughts and emotions unsecur ed, leaves a warm spirit in my  heart for your paper. I am di gesting it each week. To you, the reader, many whom I have never known, I feel a close tie in the fellowship of the Christian community. Many stopped me on their streets of Appomattox to share your ap preciation of the articles. You indicated your interest in a paper that includes religious thoughts. For your letters, and calls, I shall always be grateful. We are well settled and at work here at the First Baptist Church, Hasting, Fla. Though we miss the friendships of Ap pomattox, we are finding new friends here in this small but love ly town, which boasts of the Potato Capitol of Florida. Come to see us. The peace of God be with you. It is our hope and plan to be back next summ er as you celebrate the 100 year history of the Gentlemans Peace by Lee and Grant. O. D. Moore First Baptist Church Hastings, Fla.

document.text: with him and they didnt stop there anyway, as they- were heading for Ap-PO-xnaw-tocks and where were Th elndians. Who came the longest distance to be here? well, there was the pleasant interview I had with Mr. and Mrs. Ivan Grant. No re lation to Gen. U S Grant She is a native of Sydney, New South Wales, Australia, and he is a native of London, England. They met some four years ago, and he is now an advertising art direc tor in New York City. Fine peo ple, and while here they were oernight guests in- the hosptt- alble home of Mr. and Mrs. Lloyd! Vaughan who had made a guest room available for Centennial visitors. Wish I could have chatt ed longer with these fine visitors. Oh yes . . . it was a field day for autograph- seekers. On lady wrote and called by long dis tance to ask Mother Brightleaf to be sure to get her five auto graphs of Robert E. Lee V and fact Brlghtleaf spent most of her time getting program auto graphs fromthe above and Gov. Albertis S. HArrison Senatoi Byrd and Robertsn and Reps. Watt Abbitt, W. - Mt Tuck, and other VIPs for the souvenir hunters.

document.text: When the TIMES-VIRGINIAN observed its tenth anniver sary under the ownership of the Vaughans on Friday eve- ning, September 1st, one of the many guests stopping by was Miss Cassie Baldwin, long time correspondent for this news paper. Lloyd Vaughan, Co-Publisher, is seen in the above picture as he chats with  Miss Cassie on Fridaynight. Miss Cas sie has written, faithfully, Rocks news for the TIMES-VIR GINIAN the entire 10 years of this ownership , . . however, she has written the same column for approximately forty years in all. It is people like Miss Cassie Baldwin who make a weekly county newspaper more enjoyable for readers and her weekly Rocks news is one of the most  read columns in this paper.

document.text: W. Lloyd Vaughan STRUGGLING WITH DOUBT Scripture Genesis 15-1815 My grace is nrfftefcat for yeu, far a y pewer Is made perfect hi weakness. 2 Cor. 129 Abraham was 75 years old and childless, and his wife Sarah was 65. when God called him to leave home and kin and go to the land that I will show you. With the call to this indefinite destination came the promise to make of Abraham a great nation. Abraham obeyed the call. Over the years, God renewed His promise to make of Abraham a great nation, but a child was not born. It is not surprising that as the years passed, and no child was born, Abraham should have wondered about the fulfillment of the promise. It is natural that doublts should have arisen. Abraham and Sarah grew impatient, and Sarah gave Abraham her servant. Hagar, after the custom of the time and region, to bear him a child. A son Ishmael was born, but Ishmael was not the son of Promise. The son of promise was to be the son of the wife, not of the slave woman. Finally, when Abraham was 100 years old, a son was born to him and Sarah, Isaac, the child of promise. They had waited 25 years from the first promise for its fulfillment. Abrahams experience over this long quarter-century of waiting and wondering and wandering shows very clearly that Gods ways are not mans ways, and man does not always understand Gods ways. Where

text.snippet: W. <mark>Lloyd</mark> <mark>Vaughan</mark> STRUGGLING WITH DOUBT Scripture

highlights.snippet: W. <mark>Lloyd</mark> <mark>Vaughan</mark> STRUGGLING WITH DOUBT Scripture

document.text: W. Lloyd Vaughan Publisher and Editor subject of his thinking. Every field of human endeavor requires study, if one is to make progress in it. In the area of Christian growth the individual has many resources available for increas ing the knowledge conducive to growth. Basic, of course, is the Bible, a treasure house of spiritual knowledge. If one has available no o th e r such resource, the Bible will prove adequate. By diligent and consistent study of the Bible and practice of its teachings, many have attained spiritual maturity. Even if one has available other resources for study, whether few or many, the Bible offers the greatest am ount of assistance for spiritual growth. Paul did not have the Scripture as we know them, but in his counsel to the Colossian Christians for grow ing spiritually, he advised them to let the word of Christ dwell in you richly . . . Christians today have the word of Christ, as it is recorded in the Bible. In addition to the Bible, many helpful works are available, books, articles in religious publications, seeking to inter pret for our clearer understand ing Gods revelation of Himself as it is recorded in the S criptures. They are so numerous that one cannot read them all, so one must be selective in his choices. Paul suggests another re source for Christian growth, singing psalms and hymns and spiritual songs with thankful ness in your hearts to God.
